metadata.title: Unit 3
metadata.subject: English
metadata.description: Poetry, public speaking, animal story, journalism and communication ‚Äî consonance, formal letter, adverbials

preAssessment.question: Consonance is repetition of _____.
options: Consonant sounds especially at end of words

preAssessment.question: Who is a comp√®re at a school programme?
options: The person who hosts/announces events in order

preAssessment.question: In 'A Crow in the House', who rescues the young crow?
In 'The Brook' by Tennyson, the famous refrain is _____.
options: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'

preAssessment.question: According to Socrates, before speaking you must ask: Is it true, is it pleasant, and _____?

concepts.title: Poetry ‚Äî 'Tartary' (Dream Kingdom) and Consonance
concepts.content: Walter de la Mare's 'Tartary' is a poem of imagination ‚Äî the poet dreams of being Lord of a magical kingdom with ivory beds, golden thrones, peacocks, tigers, and exotic music. Consonance is the repetition of consonant sounds, especially at the end of words, creating pleasing rhythm ‚Äî e.g., 'Rivers silver-pale', 'pitter-patter'.

examples.text: 'My bed should be of ivory, Of beaten gold my throne'
'In my court should peacocks flaunt, And tigers haunt'
Musical instruments: harp, flute, mandoline
Consonance: 'Rivers silver-pale'; 'All's well that ends well'

keyPoints: Consonance: repetition of consonant sounds especially at end of words
Tartary: imaginary magical kingdom in the poet's dream
Exotic images: ivory, beaten gold, peacocks, tigers, zebras
Rich vocabulary: flaunt, scimitar, citron-trees, glades
Poem uses If I were ‚Äî conditional/imaginary mood
concepts.funFact: üåç Tartary was a real historical region in Central Asia ‚Äî Walter de la Mare imagined it as a magical fantasy land!

concepts.title: Speaking Skill ‚Äî How to Comp√®re a Programme
concepts.content: A comp√®re (MC) hosts a school programme by welcoming guests, announcing events in order, introducing speakers, and giving thanks. Key phrases include: welcoming the audience, requesting dignitaries to light the lamp, introducing the chief guest, announcing performances, and giving the vote of thanks.

examples.text: 'Good morning friends! It is a pleasure to welcome you all to this festive occasion.'
'I would like to request all honourable members to kindly light the traditional lamp.'
'Let us have a big round of applause for the excellent demonstration!'
Vote of thanks: 'I take the opportunity to thank all those who lent a helping hand.'

keyPoints: Comp√®re: the host/announcer of a programme
Order: welcome ‚Üí arrival ‚Üí lamp ‚Üí school song ‚Üí guests ‚Üí speeches ‚Üí performances ‚Üí prizes ‚Üí vote of thanks
Atithi Devo Bhava: Indian tradition of honouring guests as gods
Formal language: 'We solicit', 'I request', 'I extend a hearty welcome'
Keep mobiles switched off; request audience to be seated
concepts.funFact: üé§ 'MC' stands for Master of Ceremonies ‚Äî a skill used at weddings, school events, TV shows and even the Olympics opening ceremony!

concepts.title: Story ‚Äî 'A Crow in the House' by Ruskin Bond
concepts.content: Ruskin Bond's autobiographical story about Caesar, a young crow that falls from its nest and is rescued. Caesar takes over the house ‚Äî dancing on tables, stealing toothbrushes from neighbours, snapping at Aunt Mabel's spectacles. He is both a pet and a pest! His anti-social habits (stealing beans from a neighbour's garden) lead to a broken leg and ultimately his death.

examples.text: Caesar's tricks: empties matchboxes, tears newspapers, tugs dogs' tails
Collects toothbrushes: 'Most neighbours were represented by a toothbrush'
Says 'Kiss, Kiss' but pecks Aunt Mabel's spectacles off!
End: neighbour's stick breaks his leg; Caesar slowly fades away

keyPoints: Caesar: jungle crow/raven, not a carrion crow
Pet vs. pest: both at the same time!
Ruskin Bond: famous Indian English writer
Clique of one: Caesar refuses to mix with other crows ‚Äî became 'snobbish'
Anti-social behaviour ultimately leads to consequences
concepts.funFact: üê¶ Ruskin Bond actually had a crow named Caesar as a child ‚Äî this story is true! He grew up in Dehradun with many exotic pets.
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 64-67: A Crow in the House by Ruskin Bond

concepts.title: Poetry ‚Äî 'The Brook' by Tennyson
concepts.content: Alfred Lord Tennyson's 'The Brook' is narrated by the brook itself ‚Äî giving it human qualities (personification). The famous refrain 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever' contrasts the temporary nature of human life with the eternal flow of nature. The brook babbles, chatters, sparkles and sings as it flows.

examples.text: 'I come from haunts of coot and hern, I make a sudden sally'
'Here and there a lusty trout, And here and there a grayling'
'I chatter, chatter, as I flow to join the brimming river'
Refrain: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'

keyPoints: Personification: giving human qualities to a non-human thing
Refrain: a line or lines repeated at intervals in a poem
Brook's journey: from hills past farms, to join the river
Sound words: babble, chatter, bubble, murmur, slip, slide
Contrasts: temporary human life vs eternal nature
concepts.funFact: ‚è≥ Tennyson wrote 'The Brook' after losing a dear friend ‚Äî the brook's eternal flow was his way of coping with grief and change.
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 68-70: The Brook by Alfred Lord Tennyson

concepts.title: Journalism and Speech ‚Äî News Analysis and Think Before You Speak
concepts.content: News items can be good/bad, reliable/unreliable, interesting/boring. Check reliability by finding the source. Benjamin Disraeli: 'Nature gave us two ears and one mouth ‚Äî listen more, talk less.' Socrates said speak only after asking: (1) Is it true? (2) Is it pleasant? (3) Is it useful?

examples.text: News types: city, state, national, world; political, cultural, sports
Disraeli: two ears, one mouth ‚Äî listen more than you speak
Socrates' 3 questions before speaking: True? Pleasant? Useful?
Formal letter format: address, date, subject, salutation, body, closing, signature

keyPoints: Reliable news: has source, verifiable facts
Unreliable news: anonymous claims, unverified 'miracles'
Of the unspoken word you are master; of the spoken, you are a slave
Formal letter: sender's address, date, subject, Sir/Madam, body, Yours faithfully
Socrates' 3 tests for speech: true, pleasant, useful
concepts.funFact: üì± Today 'fake news' spreads in seconds on social media ‚Äî Socrates' 2400-year-old advice is more relevant than ever!
concepts.textbookRef: Pages 71-73: News Analysis; Pages 75-77: Think Before You Speak

test.question: 'Rivers silver-pale' is an example of _____.
test.explanation: Consonance is the repetition of consonant sounds especially at the end of words. In 'rivers silver-pale', the 'r' sound at the end is repeated.

test.question: In 'Tartary', the poet imagines riding in a car drawn by _____.
test.explanation: 'And zebras seven should draw my car Through Tartary's dark glades.'

test.question: What is a comp√®re's main role at a school programme?
options: To host and announce events in order
To deliver the chief guest's speech
test.explanation: The comp√®re welcomes everyone, announces events in sequence, introduces speakers, and gives the vote of thanks.

test.question: The famous refrain of 'The Brook' is _____.
options: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever'
'I come from haunts of coot and hern'
'With many a curve my banks I fret'
test.explanation: The refrain repeats in every stanza: 'For men may come and men may go, But I go on for ever' ‚Äî contrasting temporary human life with eternal nature.

test.question: Why did Caesar never go back to live with other crows?
options: He had become used to living with humans and considered himself above ordinary crows
test.explanation: Caesar had grown used to living with humans on equal terms and had become snobbish ‚Äî he did not wish to mix with his own kind.

test.question: Socrates said to speak only after asking three questions. Which is NOT one of them?
test.explanation: Socrates' three questions before speaking are: (1) Is it true? (2) Is it pleasant? (3) Is it useful? 'Is it funny?' is not one of them.

test.question: In 'The Brook', what literary device gives the brook human qualities like 'I chatter' and 'I babble'?
test.explanation: Personification gives human qualities to non-human things. The brook speaks in first person ‚Äî 'I come', 'I make', 'I chatter', 'I babble'.

test.question: What was Caesar's most anti-social habit that led to his death?
options: Stealing beans from a neighbour's garden ‚Äî a stick was flung at him
test.explanation: Caesar was stealing beans from a neighbour's garden when a stick was flung at him, breaking his leg. He never recovered.

test.question: Benjamin Disraeli said nature gave us two ears and one mouth because _____.
options: We should listen more than we speak
Hearing is more important than speaking
test.explanation: Disraeli used this humorously to make the point that if we were meant to talk more, we would have two mouths and one ear. We should listen more, speak less.

test.question: A formal letter must end with _____.
options: 'Yours faithfully' followed by signature and name
test.explanation: A formal letter (to someone you don't know personally) ends with 'Yours faithfully' followed by the sender's signature and name.

keyConcepts: Consonance: repetition of consonant sounds especially at word endings
Tartary: imaginary dream kingdom ‚Äî exotic, rich imagery
Comp√®re: host of a programme ‚Äî order of events, formal language
Atithi Devo Bhava: guests are like gods ‚Äî Indian tradition
Caesar the crow: pet vs pest ‚Äî Ruskin Bond's autobiographical story
Personification: giving human qualities to non-human things (The Brook)
Refrain: repeated line or lines in a poem
Formal letter format and reliable vs unreliable news
commonMisconceptions: Consonance = rhyme ‚Äî FALSE, consonance is middle/end consonant sounds, not necessarily full rhyme
The Brook is sad ‚Äî it is actually joyful and eternal
A comp√®re just reads a list ‚Äî FALSE, they link events with formal, engaging language
All news is reliable ‚Äî FALSE, check sources and facts
realWorldExamples: School Annual Day ‚Äî using comp√®re skills from the lesson
Reading newspapers critically ‚Äî reliable vs unreliable news
Ruskin Bond grew up in Dehradun with pets ‚Äî very relatable story
Social media 'fake news' ‚Äî Socrates' advice 2400 years later!
WhatsApp messages ‚Äî are they true, pleasant, useful before forwarding?

formulas.formula: Formal letter = Address + Date + Subject + Salutation + Body + Closing + Signature
formulas.explanation: All parts needed for a correct formal letter

interactiveElement.title: Vocabulary Flashcards!
interactiveElement.description: Flip each card to reveal the meaning of the word.

cards.back: A figure of speech comparing two unlike things without using 'like' or 'as'
Repetition of the same initial consonant sound in nearby words
A word that has the same or similar meaning as another word

cards.front: What is a 'stanza' in a poem?
cards.back: A group of lines in a poem, similar to a paragraph in prose

textbookExercise.instructions: Memorize these exam-style answers to maximize scoring in textbook-focused assessments.

longAnswers.question: What is a comp√®re's main role at a school programme?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: A comp√®re acts as the primary host or Master of Ceremonies for a school programme. Their main role is to welcome the audience and guests, ensuring everyone feels respected in line with the tradition of 'Atithi Devo Bhava'. They are responsible for announcing events in the correct sequence, starting from the lighting of the lamp to the vote of thanks. Throughout the programme, the comp√®re uses formal and polite language to link performances smoothly and keep the audience engaged.
keyPoints: Acts as the host or Master of Ceremonies (MC) for the event.
Welcomes the audience and honours guests.
Announces events in sequence, from lamp lighting to vote of thanks.
Uses formal language to link performances and engage the audience.

longAnswers.question: Why did Caesar never go back to live with other crows?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: Caesar, the young crow rescued by Ruskin Bond, never went back to live with other crows because he had grown accustomed to living with humans on equal terms. Having been raised in a human household, he developed snobbish tendencies and considered himself above ordinary crows. Instead of flying away with his own kind, he chose to stay and interact with the family and neighbours. He essentially became a 'clique of one', refusing to mix with other jungle crows.
keyPoints: Grew accustomed to living with humans on equal terms.
Developed snobbish tendencies due to his human upbringing.
Considered himself above ordinary jungle crows.
Refused to mix with his own kind, acting as a 'clique of one'.

longAnswers.question: In 'The Brook', what literary device gives the brook human qualities like 'I chatter' and 'I babble'?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: In 'The Brook', Alfred Lord Tennyson uses the literary device of personification to give the brook human qualities. By writing the poem from the first-person perspective, the brook itself becomes the narrator, speaking directly to the reader. Words like 'chatter', 'babble', and 'murmur' assign human-like actions and a voice to the flowing water. This personification helps to emphasize the active, enduring nature of the brook in contrast to the short, temporary lives of human beings.
keyPoints: Employs the literary device of personification.
The brook acts as a first-person narrator in the poem.
Assigns human actions like 'chatter' and 'babble' to the water.
Highlights the contrast between eternal nature and temporary human life.

longAnswers.question: What was Caesar's most anti-social habit that led to his death?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: While Caesar the crow had many mischievous habits like stealing toothbrushes and tearing newspapers, his most anti-social behavior involved stealing from neighbours. His fatal mistake occurred when he was caught stealing beans from a neighbour's garden. In response to the theft, the angry neighbour retaliated by flinging a stick at the bird. The stick struck Caesar and broke his leg, an injury from which the poor crow never recovered and eventually died.
keyPoints: Engaged in mischievous habits, including stealing from neighbours.
Caught stealing beans from a neighbour's garden.
An angry neighbour retaliated by flinging a stick at him.
The stick broke his leg, leading to his unfortunate death.

longAnswers.question: According to Socrates, what are the three questions one should ask before speaking?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: According to the ancient philosopher Socrates, one should carefully evaluate their words before speaking by asking three important questions. First, you must ask 'Is it true?', ensuring that you are not spreading falsehoods or unreliable information. Second, you must ask 'Is it pleasant?', checking whether your words are kind or might cause hurt. Finally, you should ask 'Is it useful?', to determine if the statement actually adds value or is simply unnecessary noise.
keyPoints: Evaluate words carefully before speaking.
Ask 'Is it true?' to avoid spreading falsehoods.
Ask 'Is it pleasant?' to ensure kindness and prevent hurt.
Ask 'Is it useful?' to make sure the words add value.

longAnswers.question: If the poet were the Lord of Tartary, what kind of life would he lead as described in the poem?
longAnswers.modelAnswer: If Walter de la Mare were the Lord of Tartary, he would lead a life of absolute luxury and grandeur. He imagines sleeping on a bed of ivory, sitting on a throne of beaten gold, and wearing robes adorned with precious pearls. His magnificent court would be filled with proud peacocks, while tigers would roam his dense forests. When traveling, he visualizes riding through the dark glades in a spectacular carriage drawn by seven zebras.
keyPoints: Would lead a life of absolute luxury and grandeur.
Imagines a bed of ivory and a throne of beaten gold.
His court would feature peacocks and his forests would have tigers.
Would travel in a carriage drawn by seven zebras.
